events.originalText: Burmese military forces killed at least 40 civilians during the Mo So massacre in Kayah State, Myanmar.
events.subtitle: Tatmadaw
events.headline: Massacre in Kayah State: Burmese military kills 40 civilians

events.originalText: The Lord's Resistance Army, a Ugandan rebel group, began attacks on several villages in the north of the Democratic Republic of the Congo, killing hundreds and committing numerous atrocities.
events.subtitle: Lord's Resistance Army
events.headline: Lord's Resistance Army attacks villages in Congo, killing hundreds

events.originalText: Jihadists linked to al-Qaeda hijacked Indian Airlines Flight 814 to force the release of Islamist figures held in prison in India.
events.subtitle: Jihadism
events.headline: Al-Qaeda linked Jihadists hijack Indian Airlines Flight 814

events.originalText: About 20,000 protestors marched in a civil rights demonstration in Forsyth County, Georgia, United States.
events.subtitle: 1987 Forsyth County protests
events.headline: 20,000 protestors march in civil rights demonstration in Georgia

events.originalText: Aeroflot Flight 601 crashed on approach to Leshukonskoye in the Russian SSR, killing 44 out of 49 people on board.
events.subtitle: Aeroflot Flight 601
events.headline: Aeroflot Flight 601 crashes in Russian SSR, 44 dead

events.originalText: The Soviet government deployed troops in Afghanistan, starting the Soviet–Afghan War.
events.subtitle: Soviet–Afghan War
events.headline: Soviet troops deployed in Afghanistan, starting war

events.originalText: The U.S. Congress granted home rule to Washington, D.C., allowing the residents to elect their own mayor and a city council.
events.subtitle: United States Congress
events.headline: U.S. Congress grants home rule to Washington, D.C.

events.originalText: Piloted by Jim Lovell, Apollo 8 became the first human spaceflight to reach and orbit the Moon (Earthrise pictured).
events.subtitle: Jim Lovell
events.headline: Apollo 8 orbits Moon in historic spaceflight

events.originalText: The Viet Cong bombed the Brinks Hotel in Saigon, killing two U.S. Army officers and raising fears of an escalation of the Vietnam War.
events.subtitle: Viet Cong
events.headline: Viet Cong bomb Brinks Hotel in Saigon, raising fears

events.originalText: According to legend, the NORAD Tracks Santa program began after children began calling the Continental Air Defense Command Center to inquire about Santa Claus's whereabouts due to a misprinted phone number in an advertisement.
events.subtitle: NORAD Tracks Santa
events.headline: NORAD Tracks Santa program begins after misprinted phone number

events.originalText: A railway bridge at Tangiwai on New Zealand's North Island was damaged by a lahar and collapsed beneath a passenger train (wreckage pictured), killing 151 people.
events.subtitle: North Island
events.headline: Railway bridge collapse in New Zealand kills 151

events.originalText: Forces united in the Kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes defeated Hungarian forces to end the occupation of Međimurje.
events.subtitle: Kingdom of Yugoslavia
events.headline: Forces defeat Hungarian occupation in Kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes

events.originalText: World War I: British and German soldiers interrupted fighting to celebrate Christmas, beginning the Christmas truce .
events.subtitle: World War I
events.headline: Christmas truce interrupts fighting in World War I

events.originalText: Seventy-three people were crushed to death in a stampede after someone falsely yelled "fire" at a crowded Christmas party in Calumet, Michigan, U.S.
events.subtitle: Italian Hall disaster
events.headline: Stampede at Christmas party in Michigan kills 73

events.originalText: Aida, one of Giuseppe Verdi's most popular operas, made its debut in Cairo, Egypt.
events.subtitle: Aida
events.headline: Aida opera debuts in Cairo, Egypt

events.originalText: Six Confederate veterans of the American Civil War founded a social club they named the Ku Klux Klan, which later became a white supremacist group.
events.subtitle: Confederate States Army
events.headline: Ku Klux Klan founded by Confederate veterans

events.originalText: The Sultanate of Brunei ceded the island of Labuan to the British Empire.
events.subtitle: Bruneian Sultanate (1368–1888)
events.headline: Brunei cedes Labuan island to British Empire

events.originalText: The Christmas carol "Silent Night" (audio featured) by Joseph Mohr and Franz Gruber was first performed in a church in Oberndorf bei Salzburg, Austria.
events.subtitle: Christmas carol
events.headline: Silent Night carol first performed in Austria

events.originalText: The United Kingdom and the United States signed a peace treaty in Ghent, present-day Belgium, ending the War of 1812.
events.subtitle: Treaty of Ghent
events.headline: UK and US sign peace treaty in Ghent, ending War of 1812

events.originalText: The Tang-dynasty poet Du Fu departed for Chengdu, where he lived for the next five years and composed poems about life in his thatched cottage.
events.subtitle: Tang dynasty
events.headline: Tang-dynasty poet Du Fu departs for Chengdu
